columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about calculating option values.

To start with, let us define options. 

**Options** are types of financial contracts which give the holder the right, but not the obligation to buy or sell a specific asset at a predetermined price, on or before its date of expiration.

## Requirement A

We are going to solve the present value of the call option using these parameters: 

|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Yield | 4%| 
|Stock Price |$75 | 
|Exercise Price  |$70 | 
|Maximum Possible Stock Price  |$91   |
|Minimum Possible Stock Price  |$67  |

To start with, let us solve the value of the option at the end of the year: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Value of Option}&=\text{Maximum Price}-\text{Exercise Price}\\[15pt]
&=\$91-\$70\\[15pt]
&=\$21
\end{aligned}$$

The possible maximum price at the end of the year is deducted from the exercise price to determine the value of the option. 

Hence, the value of the option is $21.

Next, we are going to solve the present value of the stock: 

 


$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Stock}&=\frac{\text{Minimum Price}}{(1+\text{Yield})}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$67}{(1+0.04)}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{67}{1.04}\\[20 pt]
&=\$64.42
\end{aligned}$$

The possible minimum price at the end of the year is divided by the sum of 1 and the yield rate to determine the present value of the stock. 

Hence, the present value of the stock is $64.42.

Then, we are going to solve the value of the option at the current price: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current Value of Option}&=\text{Maximum Price}-\text{Minimum Price}\\[15pt]
&=\$91-\$67\\[15pt]
&=\$24
\end{aligned}$$
 

The difference between the maximum and minimum price at the end of the year is the value of the option at the current price. 

Thus, the value of the option at the current price is $24.

Lastly, the present value of the call option is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of CO}&=\frac{\text{(CSP-PV of SP)}}{(\frac{\text{CVO}}{\text{VO}})}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{(\$75-\$64.42)}{(\frac{24}{21})}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{10.58}{1.14}\\[20pt]
&=\boxed{\$9.28}
\end{aligned}$$

Where: 

PV - Present Value \
CO - Call Option\
CSP - Current Stock Price\
CVO- Current Value of Option\
VO- Value of Option

The difference between the current stock price and the present value of the stock price is divided by the quotient of the value of the option at the current price and the option's value to determine the present value of the call option. 

Therefore, the present value of the call option is $9.28.

## Requirement B

We are going to solve the present value of the call option using these parameters: 

|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Yield | 4%| 
|Stock Price |$75 | 
|Exercise Price  |$80 | 
|Maximum Possible Stock Price  |$91   |
|Minimum Possible Stock Price  |$67  |

To start with, let us solve the value of the option at the end of the year: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Value of Option}&=\text{Maximum Price}-\text{Exercise Price}\\[15pt]
&=\$91-\$80\\[15pt]
&=\$11
\end{aligned}$$

The possible maximum price at the end of the year is deducted from the exercise price to determine the value of the option. 

Hence, the value of the option is $11.

Next, we are going to solve the present value of the stock: 

 


$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Stock}&=\frac{\text{Minimum Price}}{(1+\text{Yield})}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{\$67}{(1+0.04)}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{67}{1.04}\\[20 pt]
&=\$64.42
\end{aligned}$$

The possible minimum price at the end of the year is divided by the sum of 1 and the yield rate to determine the present value of the stock. 

Hence, the present value of the stock is $64.42.

Then, we are going to solve the value of the option at the current price: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current Value of Option}&=\text{Maximum Price}-\text{Minimum Price}\\[15pt]
&=\$91-\$67\\[15pt]
&=\$24
\end{aligned}$$
 

The difference between the maximum and minimum price at the end of the year is the value of the option at the current price. 

Thus, the value of the option at the current price is $24.

Lastly, the present value of the call option is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of CO}&=\frac{\text{(CSP-PV of SP)}}{(\frac{\text{CVO}}{\text{VO}})}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{(\$75-\$64.42)}{(\frac{24}{11})}\\[20pt]
&=\frac{10.58}{2.18}\\[20pt]
&=\boxed{\$4.85}
\end{aligned}$$

Where: 

PV - Present Value \
CO - Call Option\
CSP - Current Stock Price\
CVO- Current Value of Option\
VO- Value of Option

The difference between the current stock price and the present value of the stock price is divided by the quotient of the value of the option at the current price and the option's value to determine the present value of the call option. 

Therefore, the present value of the call option is $4.85.
